monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: The ǧamra-days, my teacher, happen when the winterdays come to and end, we call them, let’s say, today the water isn’t really cold. So we say , “Today the ǧamra-day of the water happened, today the ǧamra-day of the air happened.” And this means the air is getting warm.
Today was the ǧamra-day of the soil, the ǧamra, and today was the ǧamra-day of… yes, the air, the soil, and the water, there are three ǧamra-days.

Today, in winter, there are days in March and February which are sometimes very cold, we call this the cold of the old woman, we say the cold of the old woman, we call it the cold of the old woman. And when this kind of cold happens, and if at that time they have already planted the vegetables…
When the winter hits the vegetables, when it gets cold again, we call it ḏ̣arība. The ḏ̣arība “eats” the seed … the aubergines, the thingy, they wither.
This cold comes suddenly, the Turks say, it comes suddenly. The vegetables wither and the trees begin to shed their leaves. We call it ḏ̣arība.
In the Arab countries ḏ̣arība means tax. But we call the cold which comes suddenly ḏ̣arība.

We say, today the ḏ̣arība hit and this and that has withered immediately; the leaves are shed, the chili pepper, the aubergines, the tomatoes… and the trees begin to shed their leaves. Yes, we call it ḏ̣arība, in our language we say, today the ḏ̣arība has hit (the plants).
